author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, I cannot get that beautiful afternoon out of my head, above me where I lay the grass was silhouetted against the blue of the 
heavens, small clouds were rushing past as the wind drove them on an endless journey. <NAME> close to me was the most lovely of 
all, your soft hair against my cheek, your kisses so cool and unearthly and my happiness was so great.
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, To <NAME>
I love you no longer; on the contrary, I detest you. you are a wretch, truly perverse, truly stupid, a real <NAME> <NAME> never write
to me at all, you do not love your husband; you know the pleasure that your letters give him yet you cannot even manage to write him half
a dozen lines, dashed off in a moment! What then do you do all day, <NAME> What business is so vital that it robs you of the time to 
write to your faithful lover? What attachment can be stifling and pushing aside the love, the tender and constant love which you promised 
him? Who can this wonderful new lover be who takes up your every moment, rules your days and prevents you from devoting your attention to 
your husband?
<NAME> <NAME> one fine night the doors will be broken down and there I shall be. <NAME> truth, I am worried, my love, to have no news 
from you; write me a four page letter instantly made up from those delightful words which fill my heart with emotion and joy. I hope to 
hold you in my arms before long, when I shall lavish upon you a million kisses, burning as the equatorial sun.
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, <NAME> heart overflows with emotion and joy! I do not know what heavenly languor, what infinite pleasure permeates it and burns me up. 
It is as if I had never loved!!! <NAME> me whence these uncanny disturbances spring, these inexpressible foretastes  of delight, 
these divine, tremors of love. <NAME> all this can only spring from you, sister, angel, woman, <NAME> <NAME> this can only be, is surely 
nothing less than a gentle ray streaming from your fiery soul, or else some secret poignant teardrop which you have long since left 
in my breast.
<NAME> my <NAME> never force us apart, take pity on us! But what am I saying? Forgive my weakness, how couldst <NAME> divide us! <NAME> 
wouldst have nothing but pity for us…<NAME> no! It is not in vain that our flesh and our souls quicken and become immortal through <NAME> 
Word, which cries out deep within us Father, Father…out <NAME> hand to us, that our broken hearts seek their refuge in <NAME> we thank, 
bless and praise <NAME> O <NAME> for all that <NAME> has given us, and all that <NAME> hast prepared for us….
<NAME> is to be — to be!
<NAME> <NAME>
<NAME> let me repeat that name a hundred times, a thousand times over; for three days now it has lived within me, oppressed me, 
set me afire. I am not writing to you, no, I am close beside you. I see you, I hear you. <NAME> in your arms… <NAME> Hell, everything, 
all is within you, redoubled… <NAME> <NAME> me free to rave in my delirium. Drab, tame, constricting reality is no longer enough for me. 
We must live our lives to the full, loving and suffering to extremes!…
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME>
<NAME> let me repeat that name a hundred times, a thousand times over; for three days now it has lived within me, oppressed me, 
set me afire. I am not writing to you, no, I am close beside you.
I see you, I hear you… <NAME> in your arms…<NAME> hell, all is within you and even more than all… <NAME> <NAME> me free to rave 
in my delirium. <NAME> cautious, narrow reality is no longer enough for me. We must live out lives to the full, our loves, our 
sorrow…! <NAME> you believe me capable of self-sacrifice, chastity, temperance and piety, do you not? But let no more be said of 
this… it is for you to question, to draw conclusions, to save me as you see fit. <NAME> me be mad, senseless since you can do nothing, 
nothing at all for me. It is good for me to speak to you now. <NAME> is to be! To be!!!
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> will made by me, <NAME> <NAME>
I have not much to leave behind me, should I die next month, having my treasure deep in my heart where no one can reach it, 
and where even death cannot enter…
I want, first of all, to tell <NAME> that all I have in the world and all I am and ever shall be, belongs to him more than anyone…
<NAME> few women have been as happy as I have been every hour since I married – so few have had such a wonderful sky of love for their 
common atmosphere, that perhaps it will seem strange when I write down that the sadness of death and parting is greatly lessened to 
me by the fact of my consciousness of the eternal, indivisible oneness of <NAME> and me.
I feel as long as he is down here I must be here, silently, secretly sitting beside him as I do every evening now, however much my 
soul is the other side, and that if <NAME> were to die, we would be as we were on earth, love as we did this year, only fuller, quicker, 
deeper than ever, with a purer passion and a wiser worship.
Only in the meantime, whilst my body is hid from him and my eyes cannot see him, let my trivial toys be his till the morning comes when 
nothing will matter because all is spirit.
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME>
<NAME> I say that the human might be filed in categories? Well, and if I did, let me qualify — not all humans. <NAME> elude me. I cannot 
place you, cannot grasp you. I may boast that of nine out of ten, under given circumstances, I can forecast their action; that of 
nine out of ten, by their word or action, I may feel the pulse of their hearts. But of the tenth I despair. It is beyond me. <NAME> are 
that tenth.
Were ever two souls, with dumb lips, more incongruously matched! We may feel in common — surely, we oftimes do — and when we do not 
feel in common, yet do we understand; and yet we have no common tongue. Spoken words do not come to us. We are unintelligible. <NAME> must 
laugh at the mummery.
<NAME> one gleam of sanity through it all is that we are both large temperamentally, large enough to often understand. <NAME> we often 
understand but in vague glimmering ways, by dim perceptions, like ghosts, which, while we doubt, haunt us with their truth. <NAME> still, 
I, for one, dare not believe; for you are that tenth which I may not forecast.
Am I unintelligible now? I do not know. I imagine so. I cannot find the common tongue.
<NAME> temperamentally — that is it. It is the one thing that brings us at all in touch. We have, flashed through us, you and I, each 
a bit of universal, and so we draw together. <NAME> yet we are so different.
I smile at you when you grow enthusiastic? It is a forgivable smile — nay, almost an envious smile. I have lived twenty-five years of 
repression. I learned not to be enthusiastic. It is a hard lesson to forget. I begin to forget, but it is so little. At the best, 
before I die, I cannot hope to forget all or most. I can exult, now that I am learning, in little things, in other things; but of my 
things, and secret things doubly mine, I cannot, I cannot. <NAME> I make myself intelligible? <NAME> you hear my voice? I fear not. <NAME> are 
poseurs. I am the most successful of them all.
author: Unknown

quote:
Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> darling,
<NAME> not imagine, because you find these lines in your journal that I have been trespassing.  <NAME> know I have not – and where else shall 
I leave a love letter?  For I long to write you a love-letter tonight.
<NAME> are all about me – I seem to breathe you, hear you, feel you in me and of me.
What am I doing here?  <NAME> are away.  I have seen you in the train, at the station, driving up, sitting in the lamplight, talking, 
greeting people, washing your hands…  <NAME> I am here – in your tent – sitting at your table.
<NAME> are some wall-flower petals on the table and a dead match, a blue pencil and a <NAME> <NAME>  I am just as much at 
home as they.
When dusk came, flowing up the silent garden, lapping against the blind windows, my first and last terror started up.  I was making 
some coffee in the kitchen.  It was so violent, so dreadful I put down the coffee pot – and simply ran away – ran ran out of the studio 
and up the street with my bag under one arm and a block of writing paper and a pen under the other.  I felt that if I could get here 
and find <NAME> F I should be *safe*.
I found her and I lighted your gas, wound up your clock, drew your curtains and embraced your black overcoat before I sat down, 
frightened no longer.  <NAME> not be angry with me, <NAME>  Ca a ete plus fort que moi ….  <NAME> is why I am here.
When you came to tea this afternoon you took a brioche, broke it in half and padded the inside doughy bit with two fingers.  <NAME> 
always do that with a bun or roll or a piece of bread.  It is your way – your head a little on one side the while.
When you opened your suitcase, I saw your old <NAME> and a <NAME> book and a com all higgledy-piggedly.  ‘<NAME> <NAME> only got 3 
handkerchiefs.’ Why should that memory be so sweet to me?…
<NAME> night, there was a moment before you got into bed.  <NAME> stood, quite naked, bending forward a little, talking.  It was only for 
an instant.  I saw you – I loved you so, loved your body with such tenderness.  <NAME> my dear!
<NAME> I am not thinking of *passion*.  <NAME> of that other thing that makes me feel that every inch of you is so precious to me – your 
soft shoulders – your creamy warm skin, your ears cold like shells are cold – your long legs and your feet that I love to clasp with my 
feet – the feeling of your belly – and your thin young back.  <NAME> below that bone that sticks out at the back of your neck you have a 
little mole.
It is partly because we are young that I feel this tenderness.  I love your mouth.  I could not bear that it should be touched even by 
a cold wind if I were the <NAME>
We two, you know, have everything before us, and we shall do very great things.  I have perfect faith in us, and so perfect is my love 
for you that I am, as it were, still, silent to my very soul.
I want nobody but you for my lover and my friend and to nobody buy you shall I be faithful.
I am yours forever.
<NAME>g.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> love for you tonight is so deep and tender that it seems to be outside myself as well. I am fast shut up like a little lake 
in the embrace of some big mountains. If you were to climb up the mountains, you would see me down below, deep and shining – and 
quite fathomless, my dear. <NAME> might drop your heart into me and you’d never hear it touch bottom.
I love you – I love you. <NAME> <NAME> what it is to love like this!
PS.–while I was writing the last page, tear after tear fell on the paper. But I must cheer up — catch! — <NAME> astonishing 
number of kisses are flying about — <NAME> deuce!– I see a whole crowd of them! <NAME> <NAME> have just caught three– <NAME> are delicious!– 
<NAME> can still answer this letter, but you must address your reply to <NAME> <NAME> Restante– <NAME> is the safest course. As I do not 
yet know for certain whether I shall go to <NAME> I can’t tell you anything definite. <NAME> write on the cover that the letter 
is to be kept until called for.
<NAME> most beloved little wife– <NAME> care of your health– and don’t think of walking into town. <NAME> write and tell 
me how you like our new quarters– <NAME> 
I kiss you millions of times.
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, I have something stupid and ridiculous to tell you.  I am foolishly writing to you instead of having told you this, I do not 
know why, when returning from that walk.
To-night I shall be annoyed at having done so.  <NAME> will laugh in my face, will take me for a maker of phrases in all my relations 
with you hitherto.  <NAME> will show me the door and you will think I am lying.
I am in love with you.  I have been thus since the first day I called on you.
<NAME> de <NAME>sset
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, Could I see you without passion, or be absent from you without pain, I need not beg your pardon for thus renewing my vows that 
I love you more than health, or any happiness here or hereafter.
<NAME> you do is a new charm to me, and though I have lanquished for seven long tedious years of desire, jealously despairing, 
yet every minute I see you I still discover something new and more bewitching. <NAME> how I love you; what would I not renounce or 
enterprise for you?
I much have you mine, or I am miserable, and nothing but knowing which shall be the happy hour can make the rest of my years that 
are to come tolerable. <NAME> me a word or two of comfort, or resolve never to look on me more, for I cannot bear a kind look and after 
it a cruel denial.
<NAME> minute my heart aches for you; and, if I cannot have a right in yours, I wish it would ache till I could complain to you no longer.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, I plowed the vast ocean on a frail bit of timber; (whereas) the ship that bore the son of A<NAME> (<NAME> was strong… 
<NAME> furtive arts of <NAME> aided him; arts which I wish that <NAME> had not learned from me. He returned home; I shall die in 
these lands, if the heavy wrath of the offended <NAME> shall be lasting.
<NAME> burden, most faithful wife, is a harder one than that which the son of A<NAME> bore. <NAME> too, whom I left still young at 
my departure from the City, I can believe to have grown old under my calamities. <NAME> grant it, ye <NAME> that I may be enabled 
to see you, even if such, and to give the joyous kiss on each cheek in its turn; and to embrace your emaciated body in my arms, 
and to say, “’twas anxiety, on my account, that caused this thinness”; and, weeping, to recount in person my sorrows to you in 
tears, and thus enjoy a conversation that I had never hoped for; and to offer the due frankincense, with grateful hand, to the 
<NAME> and to the wife that is worthy of a <NAME> <NAME> in real truth!
<NAME> that the mother of <NAME> that <NAME> being softened, would with her rosy lips, speedily call forth that day.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME> Am nearly through with my writing. Am brain weary with the thousand and one imperative details and things 
to think of. <NAME> thus far has gone well, too well I am afraid, and I am (solely on general principles) somewhat suspicious 
of the future. <NAME> ship is in better shape than before; the party and crew are apparently harmonious; I have 21 Eskimo men 
(against 23 last time) but the total of men women and children is only 50 as against 67 before owing to a more careful selection 
as to children… I have landed supplies here, and leave two men ostensibly on behalf of Cook.
As a matter of fact I have established here the sub-base which last I established at <NAME> Head, as a precaution in event of 
loss of the <NAME> either going up this fall or coming down next summer. <NAME> some respects this is an advantage as on leaving 
here there is nothing to delay me or keep me from taking either side of the <NAME> going up. the conditions give me entire control 
of the situation…
<NAME> have been with me constantly, sweetheart. At <NAME> I looked repeatedly at Ptarmigan <NAME> and thought of the time we 
camped there. At Nuuatoksoah I landed where we were. <NAME> on the 11th we passed the mouth of <NAME> <NAME> in brilliant weather, and as 
long as I could I kept my eyes on <NAME> <NAME> We have been great chums dear. <NAME> <NAME> to remember what I told her, tell 
“<NAME> [<NAME> <NAME> to remember “straight and strong and clean and honest”, obey orders, and never forget that <NAME> 
put “<NAME> in his charge till he himself comes back to take her. <NAME> fancy I kiss your dear eyes and lips and cheeks sweetheart; and 
dream of you and my children, and my home till I come again. <NAME> my babies for me. Aufwiedersehen.
<NAME> <NAME> <NAME> 
<NAME> <NAME>t
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME> the poor have not need of much to sustain them — they ask only for the crumbs that fall from the rich man’s table. But if 
they are refused the crumbs they die of hunger. <NAME> do I, either, need much affection from those I love. I should not know what to do 
with a friendship entire and complete – I am not used to it. But you showed me of yore a little interest, when I was your pupil in 
<NAME> and I hold on to the maintenance of that little interest — I hold on to it as I would hold on to life.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> shall now receive (my dear wife) my last words in these my last lines. <NAME> love I send you that you may keep it when I am 
dead, and my counsel that you may remember it when I am no more.
I would not by my will present you with sorrows (dear <NAME> let them go to the grave with me and be buried in the dust. <NAME> 
seeing that it is not <NAME> will that I should see you any more in this life, bear it patiently, and with a heart like thy self.
First, I send you all the thanks which my heart can conceive, or my words can rehearse for your many travails, and care taken for 
me, which though they have not taken effect as you wished, yet my debt to you is not the less; but pay it I never shall in this world.
<NAME> I beseech you for the love you bear me living, do not hide your self many days, but by your travails seek to help your 
miserable fortunes and the right of your poor child. <NAME> mourning cannot avail me, I am but dust…
<NAME> your poor child for his father’s sake, who chose you, and loved you in his happiest times. <NAME> those letters which I wrote 
to the <NAME> wherein I sued for my life; <NAME> is my witness it was for you and yours that I desired life, but it is true that I 
disdained my self for begging of it: for know it that your son is the son of a true man, and one who in his own respect despiseth 
death and all his misshapen and ugly forms.
I cannot write much, <NAME> he knows how hardly I steal this time while others sleep, and it is also time that I should separate my 
thoughts from the world. <NAME> my dead body which living was denied thee; and either lay it at <NAME> or in Exeter <NAME> by my 
Father and <NAME> I can say no more, time and death call me away….
Written with the dying hand of sometimes they <NAME> but now alas overthrown. 
<NAME> that was, but now not my own.
<NAME> <NAME>eigh
author: Unknown

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> First <NAME>
I know tradition has it that on this morning I place cards   <NAME> <NAME> cards on your breakfast tray.  But things are 
somewhat mixed up.  I substituted a gift & delivered it a few weeks ago.
<NAME> this is the day, the day that marks 31 years of such happiness as comes to few men.  I told you once that it was like an 
adolescent’s dream of what marriage should be like.  <NAME> hasn’t changed.
<NAME> know I love the ranch but these last two days made it plain I only love it when you are there.  Come to think of it that’s 
true of every place & every time.  When you aren’t there I’m no place, just lost in time & space.
I more than love you, I’m not whole without you.  <NAME> are life itself to me.  When you are gone I’m waiting for you to return so 
I can start living again.
<NAME> <NAME> & thank you for 31 wonderful years.
I love you
<NAME> Grateful <NAME>sband
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME> <NAME>
<NAME> you know what this is–a wedding anniversary letter. I think it should arrive about on the right date. <NAME> you remember that hot 
<NAME> day thirty-three years ago?–the church jammed–Father with a lovely waistcoat with small blue spots–the <NAME> <NAME> ushers
in cutaways–the crowds in the street–your long white veil and tight little bodice–the reception at <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> 
mother with one of her extraordinary hats that stood straight up.
<NAME> do you remember what the world was then–little and cozy–a different order of things, wars considered on the basis of a <NAME> 
[<NAME> <NAME> <NAME> novel, a sort of “As it was in the beginning” atmosphere over life. We’ve come a long way down a strange road since then.
<NAME> has happened as we imagined it would except our children. We never thought we’d roam the world. We never thought our 
occupations and interests would cover such a range. We never thought that our thirty-third anniversary would find us deep in our 
second war and me again at the front. Well, darling, we’ve lived up to the most important part of the ceremony, “<NAME> sickness and 
in health, for richer for poorer, till death do you part.”
<NAME> much love.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, I don’t know anything dreadful enough to liken to you – you are like a sweet forest of pleasant glades and whispering branches – 
where people wander on and on in its playing shadows they know not how far – and when they come near the centre of it, it is all 
cold and impenetrable – and when they would fain turn, lo – they are hedged with briars and thorns and cannot escape…
<NAME> are like the bright – soft – swelling – lovely fields of a high glacier covered with fresh morning snow – which is heavenly 
to the eye – and soft and winning on the foot – but beneath, there are winding clefts and dark places in its cold – cold ice – 
where men fall, and rise not again.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME>
<NAME> happy your last letters have made me — those since <NAME> I should like to call you by all the endearing epithets, 
and yet I can find no lovelier word than the simple word ‘dear,’ but there is a particular way of saying it. <NAME> dear one, then, 
I have wept for joy to think that you are mine, and often wonder if I deserve you.
One would think that no one man’s heart and brain could stand all the things that are crowded into one day. Where do these thousands 
of thoughts, wishes, sorrows, joys and hopes come from? <NAME> in, day out, the procession goes on. But how light-hearted I was yesterday 
and the day before! <NAME> shone out of your letters so noble a spirit, such faith, such a wealth of love!
author: Unknown

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, To ‘<NAME> <NAME> <NAME>
I want my rapscallionly fellow vagabond.
I want my dark lady. I want my angel –
I want my tempter. 
I want my <NAME> with her apples. 
I want the lighter of my seven lamps of beauty, honour,
laughter, music, love, life and immortality … I want
my inspiration, my folly, my happiness,
my divinity, my madness, my selfishness,
my final sanity and sanctification,
my transfiguration, my purification,
my light across the sea,
my palm across the desert,
my garden of lovely flowers,
my million nameless joys,
my day’s wage,
my night’s dream,
my darling and
my star…
<NAME> <NAME>
author: Unknown

quote:
Dearest <NAME>, I know that when two wayfarers ‘take shelter under the same tree and slake their thirst in the same river’ it has all been determined 
by their karma from a previous life. For the past few years you and I have shared the same pillow as man and wife who had intended to 
live and grow old together, and I have become as attached to you as your own shadow. <NAME> is what I believed, and I think this is what 
you have also thought about us.
But now I have learnt about the final enterprise on which you have decided and, though I cannot be with you to share the grand moment, 
I rejoice in the knowledge of it. It is said that (on the eve of his final battle) the <NAME> general, Hsiang Yü, valiant warrior though 
he was, grieved deeply about leaving <NAME> Yü, and that (in our own country) <NAME> <NAME> lamented his parting from <NAME> 
I have now abandoned all hope about our future together in this world, and (mindful of their example) I have resolved to take the ultimate 
step while you are still alive. I shall be waiting for you at the end of what they call the road to death.
I pray that you may never, never forget the great bounty, deep as the ocean, high as the mountains, that has been bestowed upon us for 
so many years by our lord, 
<NAME> Hideyori.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME>
I lay down last night with your image in my thoughts, and have awak’d this morning in the same contemplation. <NAME> pleasing 
transport ith which I’me delighted, has a sweetnesse in it attended with a train of ten thousand soft desires, anxieties, and cares.
<NAME> day arises on my hopes with new brightnesse; youth beauty and innocence are the charming objects that steal me from myself, 
and give me joys above the reach of ambition pride or glory.  <NAME> me, <NAME> One, to throw myself at yr feet is giving myself 
the highest blisse I know of earth.
<NAME> hasten ye minutes!  <NAME> on the happy morning wherein to be ever her’s will make me look down on Thrones!
<NAME> <NAME> I am tenderly, passionately, faithfully thine,
<NAME> <NAME>eele
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, Cat: my cat: If only you would write to me: <NAME> love, oh Cat.
<NAME> is not, as it seems from the address above, a dive, a joint, saloon, etc.  but the honourable & dignified headquarters 
of the dons of the <NAME> of <NAME>
I love you.  <NAME> is all I know.  But all I know, too, is that I am writing into space: the kind of dreadful, unknown space 
I am just going to enter.  I am going to <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> <NAME> but these, though mis-spelt, *are* on the map.  <NAME> are not.
<NAME> you forgotten me?  I am the man you used to say you loved.  I used to sleep in your arms – do you remember?  But you never 
write. <NAME> are perhaps mindless of me.  I am not of you.  I love you.
<NAME> isn’t a moment of any hideous day when I do not say to myself. ‘It will be alright.  I shall go home.  <NAME> loves me.  
I love <NAME>  But perhaps you have forgotten.  If you have forgotten, or lost your affection for me, please, my Cat, let me know.  
I <NAME>
<NAME>
author: Unknown

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, I already love in you your beauty, but I am only beginning to love in you that which is eternal and ever precious – your heart, 
your soul. <NAME> one could get to know and fall in love with in one hour and cease to love it as speedily; but the soul one must 
learn to know. <NAME> me, nothing on earth is given without labour, even love, the most beautiful and natural of feelings.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, I have a thousand images of you in an hour; all different and all coming back to the same… <NAME> we love. <NAME> we’ve got the most amazing 
secrets and understandings. <NAME> whom I love, who is so beautiful and wonderful. I think of you eating omlette on the ground. I think 
of you once against a sky line: and on the hill that <NAME> morning.
<NAME> that night was wonderfullest of all. <NAME> light and the shadow and quietness and the rain and the wood. <NAME> you. <NAME> are so beautiful 
and wonderful that I daren’t write to you… <NAME> kinder than <NAME> <NAME> arms and lips and hair and shoulders and voice – you.
<NAME>
author: Unknown

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, Off you go again alone and its with a very heavy heart I part from you.  <NAME> more kisses and tender caresses for ever so long — I want 
to bury myself in you, hold you tight in my arms, make you feel the intense love of mine.
<NAME> are my very life <NAME> and every separation gives such endless heartache…
<NAME> my <NAME> <NAME> of my heart I envy my flowers that will accompany you.  I press you tightly to my breast, kiss every sweet 
place with tender love…
<NAME> bless and protect you, guard you from all harm, guide you safely and firmly into the new year.  <NAME> it bring glory and sure peace, 
and the reward for all this war has cost you.
I gently press my lips to yours and try to forget everything, gazing into your lovely eyes – I lay on your precious breast, rested my 
tired head upon it still.  <NAME> morning I tried to gain calm and strength for the separation.  
<NAME> wee one, 
<NAME> <NAME> 
<NAME> mine, Own!
author: Unknown

quote:
Dearest <NAME>, <NAME> has become very dear to me, and I am very glad that I love. <NAME> life and my love are one. “But you are faced with a 
‘no, never never'” is your reply. <NAME> answer to that is, “Old boy, for the present I look upon that ‘no, never never’ as a block 
of ice which I press to my heart to thaw.” <NAME> <NAME> famous <NAME> artist to <NAME> his brother, describing his passion 
for his cousin, <NAME> <NAME> never withdrew from her position of ‘no, never never’.
author: Unknown

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, I am a prisoner here in the name of the <NAME> they can take my life, but not the love that I feel for you. <NAME> my adorable mistress, 
to-night I shall see you, and if I had to put my head on the block to do it.
For heaven’s sake, do not speak to me in such disastrous terms as you write; you must live and be cautious; beware of madame your mother 
as of your worst enemy. What do I say? <NAME> of everybody; trust no one; keep yourself in readiness, as soon as the moon is visible; 
I shall leave the hotel incognito, take a carriage or a chaise, we shall drive like the wind to <NAME> I shall take paper and ink 
with me; we shall write our letters.
If you love me, reassure yourself; and call all your strength and presence of mind to your aid; do not let your mother notice anything, 
try to have your pictures, and be assured that the menace of the greatest tortures will not prevent me to serve you. <NAME> nothing has the 
power to part me from you; our love is based upon virtue, and will last as long as our lives. <NAME> there is nothing that I will not 
brave for your sake; you deserve much more than that. 
<NAME> my dear heart!
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, <NAME> golden child, my pearl, my precious stone, my crown, my queen and empress.  <NAME> dear darling of my heart, my highest and most 
precious, my all and everything, my wife, the baptism of my children, my tragic play, my posthumous reputation.  <NAME>  <NAME> are my 
second better self, my virtues, my merits, my hope, the forgiveness of my sins, my future sanctity, O little daughter of heaven, my 
child of <NAME> my intercessor, my guardian angel, my cherubim and seraph, how I love you!

quote:
My Dearest <NAME>, …it is so easy a thing for you to lift me to <NAME> <NAME>  <NAME> soul was darker than midnight, when your pen said 
“let there be light.”  and there was light as at the bidding of the Word…  When I read in your looks and words that you love me, 
I feel it in the deepest part of my soul; and then I care not one straw for the whole <NAME> beside…

quote:
My Beloved <NAME>, <NAME> would have been the making of an accomplished flirt in me, because my lucidity shows me each move of the game – 
but that, in the same instant, a reaction of contempt makes me sweep all the counters off the board and cry out: – 
“<NAME> them all – I don’t want to win – I want to lose everything to you!”
author: Unknown

quote:
To the One I Cherish, <NAME>, <NAME> noble, incomparable <NAME>
I do not know how to express or analyze the conflicting emotions that have surged like a storm through my heart all night long. 
I only know that first and foremost in all my thoughts has been the glorious confirmation you gave me last night – without effort, 
unconsciously, as of course – of all I have ever thought of your mind and heart.
<NAME> have the greatest soul, the noblest nature, the sweetest, most loving heart I have ever known, and my love, my reverence, my 
admiration for you, you have increased in one evening as I should have thought only a lifetime of intimate, loving association could 
have increased them.
<NAME> are more wonderful and lovely in my eyes than you ever were before; and my pride and joy and gratitude that you should love me 
with such a perfect love are beyond all expression, except in some great poem which I cannot write.
<NAME> own, <NAME>
author: Unknown

quote:
My Love, <NAME>, I would have liked to have dined with you today, after finishing your essay – that my eyes, and lips, I do not exactly mean my voice, 
might have told you that they had raised you in my esteem.  What a cold word!  I would say love, if you will promise not to dispute 
about its propriety, when I want to express an increasing affection, founded on a more intimate acquaintance with your heart and understanding.
I shall cork up all my kindness – yet the fine volatile essence may fly off in my walk – you know not how much tenderness for you 
may escape in a voluptuous sigh, should the air, as is often the case, give a pleasurable movement to the sensations, that have been 
clustering round my heart, as I read this morning – reminding myself, every now and then, that the writer loved me.
<NAME> is often expressive of a meaning I do not now intend to give, I would describe one of those moments, when the senses are 
exactly tuned by the ringing tenderness of the heart and according reason entices you to live in the present moment, regardless of 
the past or future – it is not rapture – it is sublime tranquility.
I have felt it in your arms – hush!  <NAME> not the light see, I was going to say hear it – these confessions should only be uttered – 
you know where, when the curtains are up – and all the world shut out – <NAME> me!
I wish I may find you at home when I carry this letter to drop it in the box, – that I may drop a kiss with it into your heart, to 
be embalmed, till me meet, closer.
author: Unknown

quote:
Dearest <NAME>, To <NAME>
<NAME> now listen to me in turn. <NAME> have touched me more profoundly than I thought even you could have touched me – my heart was full 
when you came here today. <NAME> I am yours for everything….
– <NAME> <NAME> <NAME>
